column9: you probably have to write your own 3d engine with tile system, then import all the gamerules code into it to make it or something
but programmed more in Ogre3D
there are lots of details to be considered still
yeah, I know about ogre too.... both irrlicht and oger are like bsd/mit license
yep
the tile system is one of the first problems so far, because simutrans supports huge maps
and iplementing it with terrains uses lots of memory, and you easily get over 2G
which is the hard part about is specifically?
you want the technical details?
yes and no.... more like the specific area that is causing the problem
sure, it's nice to speak with about this :)
is it trying to display all the tiles (the actual displaying)?
the thing is, mainly memory usage
it's not a fps issue
as in keeping the whol map in memory in order to do calculations on the simulation (passenger/mail, etc...)?
simutrans represents the terrain geometry as you can guess as a bidimensional array of heights
that's ok, and it's working good
the thing is when you import that into a 3D terrain, the number of vertexes grows very quick
because each tile must be represented on about 4 vertexes at minimum
if you do it manually
I truied using the current terrain building module in ogre, and "sculpt" the surface to it
and the program ran over 2 Gb
oh.... well one optimization, would be to merge flat areas into one big polygon instead of each tile in the flat area being separate polygons (but that doesnt help a lot I guess)
one option is generating the "mesh" and swap to disk, just loading the needed part
let me fix the train.... then read up on your replies....
you can do all those optimizations, but then you got LOD for example
I'm still trying to figure how to implement all that
there are plenity of things that need coding and testing
so you are loading the ENTIRE map into memory graphics?
unfortunately, I don't know how real games do it.... so I'm not much help :(

and thatw as just the map, reproducing the current simutrans graphics can be done using a identity projection matrix in OpenGL, but the thing is that right now simutrans draws all images once every frame
while the good way to do it in OpenGL is just simutrans mantaining a vertex buffr with the visible objects, not writing it completely every frame, that's not feasible due the limitations of PCI buses
and more problems, lots of problems
I may be wrong, but perhaps trying to use 3d (unless you actually make the game full 3d) might not be as efficient as the current 2d system?
I know you can use opengl to accelerate the current 2d system, however
you should get speedups, without a complete change
requires much coding and changes but I think it can be done
in fact games like simcity 4 do it
tmy current idea is going that way, and later, add 3D models
simcity 4 is some weird mix....
that's the mix I want to achieve
the bulidings in sim city 4 are still 2d images.... I don't know about the terrain, is that actually 3d?
exactly as you say
and it is my guess (and it is only a guess) that the engine has like a very basic invisible 3d box that defines the general location of the building
what do you think about it
while the bulding still is a 2d images
there are various aproaches to it
because I know all buldings are first made as 3d, then *converted* to a series of images the game actually uses
the first I experienced in was rendering all in 3D
so it is my guess that you could also extract extra info while you render the 3d images.... like the height of the 3d object, a box to represent the basic width of it etc....
but 2D images were in fact just small squares allways facing the camera, theya re called billboards in ogre2D
oh, I'm still referring to sim city 4.... the buldings were all 2d images. I know that for sure.
yes
buildings were 2D
vehicles and terrain 3D
However, you had to actually make the buildings as 3d models... it would then render the 4 different perspectives for the game to use

mmm... in that implementation taht was a problem, yes
are you actually required to store the entire mesh (all the 3d vertices) from the entire map in memory at same time to render it on the graphics card?
on that specific problem I ended thinking about generating the grid of the terrain and save it to a file
and just swap the map from/to memory when needed
since I don't know enough about rendering on the graphics card, is the following possible:
no, it's not needed, in fact the library splits the terrain into chunks and loads them just when necessary
1. keeping the storage of the map like it currently is
2. checking the viewport area (the tiles you are looking at) and converting the simutrans data only for that area into vertices
I'm guessing this is way too much work for realtime?  or you can't send that much data over the pci bus?
option 2 is actually a good idea too
it's not actually 2 different options, but both together :)
should be ok, because that info it's not transmitted on PCI every fram, just when the camera moves
